issue.title: Clean up heap on success
issue.body: Using `goto` isn't great but at least you won't leak this way.

comment.body: Thanks @franziskuskiefer. I want to avoid the goto's to keep the style consistent with our other example program. So I made a simpler version in #603, and checked it with valgrind. Does that look okay to you?

issue.title: Use OpenSSL's EVP_MD_CTX_new and _free
issue.body:
Fixes #565.

Does so by requiring OpenSSL version 1.1.0 or higher.  But one of our target platforms (Ubuntu Xenial 16.04) only comes with OpenSSL 1.0.2.  So what should we do?  Require users on that platform to build OpenSSL 1.0.2 (and update our Docker images accordingly)?  Or remove that as a target platform?  Thoughts, @baentsch and @xvzcf?

comment.body: - [ ] Before merging make sure https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/pull/139 is also working

issue.title: Added assembly optimization for sike
issue.body: Added assembly optimization for sike. Added detection of the bmi2 instruction set to enable MULX. The adx set however cannot be detected using the same mechanism; not sure why (perhaps I need to switch to [this script](https://github.com/autoconf-archive/autoconf-archive/blob/master/m4/ax_ext.m4) instead.)

comment.body: If you try rebasing on #597 you will get the macOS CI switched over to CircleCI, and then you should be able to get SSH access for a debug job on that.

issue.title: Add continuous integration test for memory leaks
issue.body:
Possibly using valgrind?

Would have caught #601, #600, #603.

comment.body:
I'd recommend adding sanitizer builds. But for enabling them all the issues need to get fixed first.
I opened PR #605 as one possible way to detect these issues.

issue.title: Add sanitizer builds
issue.body: A very simple `--with-sanitizer` to enable ASAN and UBSAN. This will produce a couple errors that will need to get fixed before this should be enabled on CI. Note that this should always go along with  `CC=clang`.

comment.body:
Oh, looks like that flag didn't work. That's what happens when you enable the sanitizers :wink: 
My autoconf skills are a little limited :neutral_face:

issue.title: Add sanitizer builds
issue.body: A very simple `--with-sanitizer` to enable ASAN and UBSAN. This will produce a couple errors that will need to get fixed before this should be enabled on CI. Note that this should always go along with  `CC=clang`.

comment.body: Thanks for trying. :)  We're also not great at autoconf so we're in the process of switching to CMake.  I'll see what I can do to get this working.

issue.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
issue.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are:
1. Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)
2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)
3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.
4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of windows and macOS variants)

#2 #10

comment.body:
I have updated the ReadMe.md and tested on macOS. You could now build on both windows and macOS using dotnet cli. (Testing is impossible for now due to the prebuild event for test case to pass here)

A few sample scripts have been added for sample command lines to customize the build. I would recommend .net core 2.1 and above to make life easier. I couldn’t figure out how to run .net core 1.1 outside of visual studio considering it doesn’t allow self contained app and keep complaining about missing configuration despite installing the runtime.

comment.body: For macOS and Linux, how does one install the required .NET toolchain?  On macOS I see that brew has a few packages (dotnet, dotnet-sdk) -- should I use those?  Similarly on Ubuntu or Debian, is there an apt package to install, or some other way?
